title: Brake Fluid - Renew

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall resulting in motorcycle damage, serious injury or death.

Make sure absolute cleanliness when adding brake fluid to the brake fluid reservoir. Do not allow moisture or debris to enter the cylinder, as this will adversely affect the fluid properties. Always use fluid from a sealed container and do not use fluid from a container that has been opened for any period of time. Always check for fluid leakage around hydraulic fittings and for damage to hoses. A dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident could result if this warning is ignored.

Do not allow the fluid level to fall below the lower level mark in the reservoir. If the fluid level is allowed to fall below this mark, air may enter the system and the sequence of bleeding must be repeated.
Notice - Do not spill brake fluid
To prevent paint damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Spilled brake fluid will damage paintwork.
Note the original setting of the brake lever adjusters in order that they can be returned to the same position when the bleeding operation is complete.
Turn the span adjuster fully clockwise to set the brake lever to maximum span.
Turn the ratio adjuster to its maximum setting of 21 (21 mm).
Turn the handlebars to bring the fluid reservoir to a level position.

body.name: Bleeding the Front Brakes, Renewing Brake Fluid (abdj_2 (NN, NN2, NN3, NN4, Service Manual, Brakes).svg)

body.body: Remove the screws from the brake reservoir cover.

Make sure absolute cleanliness when adding brake fluid to the brake fluid reservoir. Do not allow moisture or debris to enter the cylinder as this will adversely affect the fluid properties. Always use fluid from a sealed container and do not use fluid from a container which has been opened for any period of time. Always check for fluid leakage around hydraulic fittings and for damage to hoses.
A dangerous riding condition leading to an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
To prevent body damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.
Carefully remove the reservoir cover taking care not to spill any fluid.
Check the condition of the sealing diaphragm for the reservoir. Replace if necessary.
Remove the rubber cap from the bleed screw on the right hand caliper.
Attach a transparent tube to the bleed screw.
Place the other end of the tube in a suitable receptacle containing new brake fluid. Keep the tube end below the level of fluid.

The bleed screws should only be opened by a small angle, just enough to allow system pressure to drop. When pulling the brake lever or pushing the caliper pistons in, some resistance should be felt indicating that the screw is not opened too much.

Pressure applied to the brake lever during the brake fluid renew process must be applied and removed smoothly and slowly. It must take a minimum of five seconds between lever positions (from fully released to stop).
Failure to do this slowly can allow air to be drawn in to the system through the bleed screw threads.
Get an assistant to slowly pull the brake lever to the handlebar and then slowly release the brake lever.
Repeat step 11 until fresh brake fluid appears in the bleed tube.
When fresh brake fluid is in the system, apply pressure to the brake lever, close the bleed screw and tighten it to
Remove the bleed tube and replace the bleed screw cap.
Fill the reservoir to the upper level with new DOT 4 fluid.
Repeat steps 7 to 15 for the other front brake caliper.

When the brake fluid has been renewed, make sure the brake lever operation has a firm resistive feel to it, does not feel spongy and that the lever cannot be pulled directly back to the handlebar. Take remedial action as necessary.
If fitted, fit the insert into the cap so that the raised area is fitted away from the cap.
Fit the diaphragm seal into the cap and make sure that the holes for the fixings in the cap, insert and the diaphragm seal are correctly aligned.
Install the fixings into the cap and diaphragm seal assembly.
Hold the assembly together and position the insert, cap, diaphragm seal and fixings onto the reservoir.
Reservoir cap, diaphragm seal and fixing assembly
If the master cylinder reservoir cap screws are over tightened this can result in a brake fluid leak.
A dangerous riding condition leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident could result if this warning is ignored.

Always return the lever adjuster to the riders preferred setting. Operating the motorcycle with lever settings that are unfamiliar may lead to loss of control or an accident.

It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes; you must have your authorised Triumph dealer take remedial action before you attempt to ride the motorcycle again. Failure to take remedial action may reduce braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.

Use only DOT 4 specification brake fluid as listed in the general information section of this manual. The use of brake fluids other than those DOT 4 fluids listed in the general information section may reduce the efficiency of the braking system leading to an accident.
Observe the brake fluid handling warnings given earlier in this section of the manual.
Once the bleeding operation is completed reset the span and ratio adjusters to the riders preferred setting as noted prior to setting the maximum adjustment.
To prevent body damage, do not spill brake fluid onto any area of the bodywork.

Make sure absolute cleanliness when adding brake fluid to the brake fluid reservoir. Do not allow moisture or debris to enter the cylinder as this will adversely affect the fluid properties. Always use fluid from a sealed container and do not use fluid from a container which has been opened for any period of time. Always check for fluid leakage around hydraulic fittings and for damage to hoses.
A dangerous riding condition leading to an accident could result if this warning is ignored.
Unscrew and remove the rear brake reservoir cover taking care not to spill any fluid.
Undo and remove the fixings securing the rear brake caliper to the caliper carrier and manoeuvre the caliper clear off the brake disc.

Obtain a suitable, wide, flat metal plate which is approximately 5 mm thick and place it between the brake pads. Pump the rear brake pedal until the metal plate is held in place by the brake pads. Make sure the brake fluid level does not drop below the minimum mark.
Position the caliper so that the bleed screw is above the highest point of the brake caliper.
Remove the rubber cap from the caliper bleed screw.

Whilst supporting the rear brake caliper, attach a transparent tube to the bleed screw and place the other end of the tube in a suitable receptacle containing new brake fluid. Keep the tube end below the level of fluid.

Pressure applied to the brake pedal during the brake fluid renew process must be applied and removed smoothly and slowly. It must take a minimum of five seconds between lever positions (from fully released to stop).
Failure to do this slowly can allow air to be drawn in to the system through the bleed screw threads.

The bleed screw should only be opened by a small angle, just enough to allow system pressure to drop. When pulling the brake lever or pushing the caliper pistons in, some resistance should be felt indicating that the screw is not opened too much.
Support the caliper so that the bleed screw is uppermost.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake pedal five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.
Open the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake pedal five times, maintaining pressure on the final application.
Open the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Leave the bleed screw slightly open and slowly release the brake lever.
Slowly apply and slowly release pressure to the brake lever five times.
Close the bleed screw slightly to allow fluid to flow out but to still feel resistance in the brake lever.
Repeat steps 8 to 15 until no more air appears in the bleed tube/container.
With the brake lever still applied tighten the bleed screw to
Fill the reservoir to the upper level with new DOT 4 fluid from a sealed container.
Position the caliper over the brake disc making sure the pads are correctly aligned on both sides of the disc.
Fit the caliper retaining fixings, and tighten to
Attach the ABS sensor harness to its clamps under the swinging arm as noted for removal.
Check the condition of the sealing diaphragm. Replace the diaphragm as necessary.
Refit the reservoir cap making sure the diaphragm seal is correctly positioned between the cap and the reservoir body.
Check the operation of the rear brake. Rectify as necessary.
It is dangerous to operate the motorcycle with defective brakes.
Take remedial action before attempting to ride the motorcycle.
Failure to take remedial action may reduce braking efficiency leading to loss of motorcycle control and an accident.
